texts.title: Humane Nature; or, the Fundamental Elements of Policie
texts.sourceDesc: <cite>Humane Nature; or, The Fundamental Elements of Policie</cite> was first published in 1650. Our copytext is the posthumous 3rd edition of 1684, which claims, on its title page, to be ‘Augmented and much corrected by the Authors own hand’, and which has been transcribed and made publicly available at EEBO-TCP.

texts.title: De Corpore Politico; or, The Elements of Law, Moral and Politick
texts.sourceDesc: <cite>De Corpore Politico; or, The Elements of Law, Moral and Politick</cite> was first published in 1650. Our copytext is the posthumous edition of 1652, because we are not aware of any reason doubt the quality of this edition, and a transcription of it is available at EEBO-TCP.

texts.title: De Cive; Or, Philosophicall Rudiments Concerning Government and Society
texts.sourceDesc: De Cive was first published in Latin in 1642, and then published in English in 1651, as Philosophicall Rudiments Concerning Government and Society. Our copytext is this first English edition. Though the first to be published, it was destined to become the last of a three-part set. Part one, De Corpore, was published in 1655, followed by part two, De Homine, in 1658. Both of these were in Latin; Hobbes never published De Homine in English, but an English version of De Corpore appeared in 1656, as The Elements of Philosophy, The First Section, Concerning Body.

texts.title: Leviathan, or The Matter, Forme, & Power of a Common-Wealth Ecclesiastical and Civill
texts.sourceDesc: The text here is from the 1909 Clarendon Press edition (now in the public domain), as put online by the Online Libary of Liberty. That edition follows the original 1651 edition, but with corrections from the printed ERRATA sheet incorporated into the text.

texts.title: Of Libertie and Necessitie
texts.sourceDesc: The text here follows the original edition, as digitized by EEBO-TCP.

texts.title: De Corpore; Or, Elements of Philosophy, The First Section, Concerning Body
texts.sourceDesc: De Corpore was first published in Latin in 1655, and then published in English in 1656, as The Elements of Philosophy, The First Section, Concerning Body. Our copytext is this first English edition. As the English title indicates, it was apparently conceived as the first part of a larger work. Part 2, De Homine, was published in Latin in 1658, but never appeared in English translation (and is therefore not included on this site). Part 3, De Cive, was in fact the first part Hobbes wrote, and was published in Latin in 1642. It was also the first to appear in translation, published in 1651 as Philosophicall Rudiments Concerning Government and Society.

texts.title: Behemoth; Or, An Epitome of the Civil Wars of England, from 1640 to 1660
texts.sourceDesc: Hobbes's history of the English Civil Wars was first published in 1679. A posthumous edition was printed in 1682, claiming to be derived from the author's own copy, and to be much more accurate. So far as we are aware this claim is to be taken at face value, and consequently this edition has been chosen as our copytext.

texts.title: An Answer to a Book published by Dr. Bramhall
texts.sourceDesc: Hobbes's reply to Bramhall's criticism, in his The Catching of the Leviathan (1655), was first published posthumously in 1682.
